questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of recurrent lesions on lips as shown in the image below, which is associated with fever. What is the characteristic feature seen in Tzanck smear? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multinucleated giant cells

 

The patient presents with recurrent vesicular lesions on the lips associated with fever, which is characteristic of Herpes labialis caused by the Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). This condition is often triggered by fever and is hence also called a "fever blister" or "cold sores."

 

Another condition with recurrent lesions at the same site, typically triggered by a particular medication each time the patient is exposed to it is “Fixed Drug Eruption”. But here the initial appearance of vesicles on the lips is noted. These vesicles are prone to rupture. Once ruptured, the vesicles transform into erosions and ulcers with polycyclic margins, characteristic of herpes labialis. A history of fever is important as it often triggers these outbreaks.

 

On a Tzanck smear, the characteristic finding for Herpes labialis is the presence of multinucleated giant cells and acantholytic cells. These multinucleate giant cells are formed by the fusion of infected cells, leading to the appearance of multiple nuclei within a single cell. The Tzanck smear is specifically used in dermatology to diagnose viral infections, particularly Herpes simplex and Varicella-zoster.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Henderson Patterson bodies: These are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum, a viral infection caused by a poxvirus. These are not associated with Herpes labialis and are not found on a Tzanck smear for this condition.

 

 

Option C. Acanthocytes: These are spiny red blood cells that are typically seen in liver diseases such as cirrhosis and in certain neurological disorders. They are not related to the findings in a Tzanck smear or Herpes labialis. Although "acantholytic cells" can also be seen in Herpes labialis, these are different from acanthocytes.

 

 

Option D. Owl eye appearance: This term describes the characteristic appearance of cells infected by Cytomegalovirus (CMV), where the nucleus shows a large inclusion giving it an "owl eye" look. This is not a feature of Herpes labialis and would not be seen on a Tzanck smear for this condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear is the characteristic diagnostic feature for Herpes labialis (HSV-1).

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Based on the given information, the most likely diagnosis for the 3-year-old male with buccal mucosa findings followed by a rash after three days is Measles.

 

  • Measles is a viral illness that commonly affects children. It typically starts with flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes.
  • One of the hallmark signs of measles is the presence of Koplik spots, which are small, white, grain-like lesions that appear on the buccal mucosa.
  • A rash usually follows the appearance of Koplik spots. This rash typically starts on the face and neck and then spreads to the rest of the body.
  • If you suspect that a child has measles, it is essential to isolate them and refer them to a healthcare facility for further evaluation and treatment.
  • Lymphadenopathy may also be present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leukoplakia: Leukoplakia is a benign condition characterized by white patches on the mucous membranes. It is not associated with fever and rash.

 

Option C. Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci and presents with a URI (upper respiratory infection) and a sandpaper-like rash. It does not have Koplik spots.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis but lacks Koplik spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles is characterized by the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa followed by a widespread rash, starting from the face and neck.

questions.text: A patient is found to have a solitary thyroid nodule. What is the first step in his management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Thyroid profile/TSH

 

The initial evaluation of a solitary thyroid nodule begins with a thyroid profile, specifically measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. This is the first step because the TSH test helps determine whether the nodule is functioning (producing thyroid hormone) or non-functioning. If TSH is suppressed, indicating a hyperfunctioning (autonomous) nodule, further evaluation with a radionuclide scan may be appropriate to assess whether the nodule is "hot" (functioning). If TSH is normal or elevated, the next steps typically include an ultrasound (USG) of the neck and possibly fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy, depending on ultrasound findings. The management plan is tailored based on these initial results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radioiodine with I123: This diagnostic scan is typically used after initial thyroid function tests suggest a hyperfunctioning nodule. It is not the first step.

 

Option C. Radioiodine with I131: I131 is primarily used for therapeutic purposes, such as treating hyperthyroidism or certain types of thyroid cancer, not for initial diagnostic evaluation of a thyroid nodule.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): CECT is not routinely used as the first step in the evaluation of thyroid nodules due to its limited ability to characterize thyroid nodules compared to ultrasound and potential interference with subsequent radioactive iodine therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of a solitary thyroid nodule is to assess thyroid function with a TSH test. This guides further diagnostic and management strategies based on whether the nodule is functioning or not.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female who had a lumbar puncture continues to have a headache. Which of the following is not recommended? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fluid restriction

 

The patient is experiencing a post-dural puncture headache (PDPH), which can occur after a lumbar puncture due to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). This type of headache is typically treated with a variety of supportive measures to alleviate symptoms and promote healing.

 

Fluid restriction is not recommended for patients with PDPH.  In fact, liberal fluid intake is advised to help replace the lost CSF and maintain adequate hydration, which can aid in reducing the headache.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low volume blood patch: An epidural blood patch is an effective treatment for PDPH, particularly in refractory cases. It involves injecting a small amount of the patient's own blood into the epidural space to seal the CSF leak.

 

Option B. Increase caffeine: Caffeine is known to help reduce the severity of PDPH due to its vasoconstrictive properties, which can help alleviate the headache.

 

Option D. Stool softeners: Stool softeners are recommended to prevent straining during bowel movements, which can exacerbate the headache. Constipation is common in postoperative patients due to the use of anesthetics and other medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of post-dural puncture headache, fluid restriction is not recommended. Instead, measures such as epidural blood patches, increased caffeine intake, and stool softeners are utilized to manage symptoms and promote recovery.

questions.text: During a police investigation, bones are uncovered at the crime scene. What key characteristic feature would be crucial in differentiating between human and animal bones, aiding forensic analysis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Precipitin test

 

When differentiating between human and animal bones found at a crime scene, the key characteristic feature that aids forensic analysis is the species-specific differentiation. In such cases, regardless of the type of tissue (e.g., blood, semen, tissues, or bone), the precipitin test is the test of choice. In the precipitin test, an extract of the bone, tissue, or stain is taken, and an anti-human serum is added to it. If the sample is of human origin, a precipitate will form, indicating a positive result for human tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Acid phosphatase: Acid phosphatase is a specific test used for detecting semen and is not relevant for differentiating between human and animal bones.

 

Option. C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is another test used for detecting semen and is not applicable for differentiating between human and animal bones.

 

Option. D. Phenolphthalein test : This test is a presumptive test to detect blood stain. Also known as (Kastle-Meyer) test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The precipitin test is the key characteristic feature used to differentiate between human and animal bones found at a crime scene. This test is species-specific and can be applied to various tissues, including blood, semen, and bones. The formation of a precipitate upon the addition of an anti-human serum to the sample extract indicates the presence of human tissue.

questions.text: What is the action of the superior oblique muscle? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion, abduction, depression

 

  • The superior oblique muscle is responsible for three actions: intorsion, depression, and abduction.
  • Each eye has six extraocular muscles: four recti muscles and two oblique muscles.
  • The recti muscles are the superior, inferior, medial, and lateral rectus.
  • The superior oblique muscle originates from the apex of the orbit, turns around the trochlea, and inserts into the sclera behind the equator.
  • The tendon's oblique direction gives it a rotator effect, resulting in intorsion, as well as depression and abduction.
  • These muscles control both unilateral and binocular movements of the eye.
  • Unilateral eye movements are called Ductions.
  • Bilateral eye movements are called Versions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: 60-year-old obese lady underwent cholecystectomy. After 3 days she develops respiratory distress. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation

 

The patient, an obese post-operative case following cholecystectomy, presents with respiratory distress three days after surgery. This is highly suggestive of a pulmonary embolism, particularly in the context of immobilization and the hypercoagulable state following surgery. Pulmonary embolism is a common and serious complication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can occur due to immobilization and endothelial injury during surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Air embolism: This is less likely in this scenario as it typically occurs immediately during or after surgical procedures involving vascular access.

 

Option C. Atelectasis: While atelectasis can cause respiratory distress post-operatively, it typically does not cause sudden severe symptoms three days post-op.

 

Option D. Myocardial Infarction: Although possible, the context of recent surgery and immobilization makes pulmonary embolism a more likely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-operative patients, particularly those who are obese and immobilized, the development of sudden respiratory distress should raise suspicion for pulmonary embolism due to the increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and subsequent embolization. Prompt diagnosis and management are crucial.

 

Note - The rule of threes (in Immobilization) whenever the patient is immobilized for more than 72 hours/ >3 days in the last 3 months that is called significant immobilization and that increases the risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A child was born after 8 months of the father’s death. Grandparents filed a case that the baby might not be their son’s, but DNA came positive. What is such a child called? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posthumous child

 

A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of either parent. In this scenario, the child was born 8 months after the father's death, which fits the definition of a posthumous child. The grandparents doubted the child’s legitimacy, but DNA testing confirmed the biological connection, validating the child's status as the deceased father's offspring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suppositious child: A suppositious child is a term used to describe a fraudulent or fake child who is falsely presented as an heir, often to claim property or inheritance. This does not apply in this case because the DNA test confirmed the child’s legitimacy as the biological offspring.

 

Option B. Fictitious child: A fictitious child is purely an imaginary or invented figure that does not exist in reality, often found in literature or imagination. This term is unrelated to the case as it refers to nonexistent entities, unlike the real, biologically confirmed child in question.

 

Option D. Illegitimate child: An illegitimate child is one born outside of marriage or not legally recognized as belonging to the mother's husband. In this case, the DNA test confirmed that the child is indeed the biological offspring of the deceased father, making the term irrelevant here.

 

Educational Objective:


A posthumous child is one born after the death of a parent, as seen in this scenario where the child was born 8 months after the father's death.

questions.text: Which of the following plasma protein will decrease in acute inflammation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

In the context of acute inflammation, most plasma proteins, known as acute-phase reactants, typically increase due to the influence of cytokines like interleukin-6 (IL-6) and interleukin-1 (IL-1). These are referred to as positive acute-phase reactants.

 

However, there are certain proteins, called negative acute-phase reactants, that decrease during acute inflammation. Albumin is one such protein. The decrease in albumin during inflammation is thought to help conserve amino acids for the production of more essential proteins needed during the inflammatory response. Additionally, lower albumin levels help to reduce blood viscosity and facilitate the movement of immune cells to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CRP: C-reactive protein (CRP) is a well-known positive acute-phase reactant. Its levels significantly increase during inflammation, making it a common marker for detecting inflammation.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: Hepcidin is another positive acute-phase reactant. It increases during inflammation and plays a role in iron metabolism, often contributing to the anemia seen in chronic disease.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Ferritin, an iron-storage protein, also acts as a positive acute-phase reactant. Its levels rise during inflammation, reflecting increased storage of iron in the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negative acute-phase reactants – Albumin, Transferrin, Transthyretin

 

Positive acute-phase reactants - CRP, hepcidin, and ferritin

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with weakness in his lower limbs and rash over the eyelids. The biopsy shows inflammation of the muscle. What is the finding shown in the image below? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gottron's papules

 

  • The finding shown in the image is Gottron's papules.
  • The given scenario of a patient with weakness, rash on eyelids (Heliotrope Rash), muscle inflammation, and presence of Gottron's papules which are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis, especially in the paediatric population, known as Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM).
  • These are erythematous to violaceous papules or plaques found over bony prominences, particularly the knuckles, elbows, knees, and toes.

 

Other features associated with Dermatomyositis are:

 

The Gottron's sign

 

  • It is the distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.

 

 

Gottron's sign: seen in the above image

 

Other Options: 

 

Option C. Heliotrope rash

 

  • It is another characteristic finding of dermatomyositis, presenting as an erythematous to violaceous rash on the upper eyelids, often accompanied by periorbital edema.

 

 

Image showing Heliotrope rash:

 

  • While the patient has a rash over the eyelids, the image does not show this area.

 

Option B. Shawl sign or V-sign:

 

  • Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as seen in the image below

 

 

  • Periungual telangiectasias: enlarged capillaries in the nail folds.

 

 

  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

 

 

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Option D. Scleroderma:

 

  • It is a connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and tightening, which can also involve internal organs. The lesions in scleroderma are not typically papular as shown in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In juvenile dermatomyositis, Gottron's papules are erythematous to violaceous raised lesions typically found over the extensor surfaces of joints and serve as a key clinical marker for the disease.

questions.text: Drug of choice for malaria (plasmodium vivax) in pregnancy? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

 

The treatment of malaria in pregnancy, especially caused by Plasmodium vivax, requires special consideration due to the potential effects on both the mother and the fetus. The key points are:

 

  • Chloroquine: Chloroquine is the drug of choice for treating Plasmodium vivax malaria in pregnant women. It is effective and safe during pregnancy.
  • Alternative Drugs: If there is resistance to chloroquine, quinine can be used as a secondary option.
  • For Plasmodium falciparum malaria, artesunate is the preferred drug, followed by quinine, both of which can be safely used during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine + Primaquine: This combination is not used in pregnancy due to the contraindication of primaquine. Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy because it can cause hemolytic anemia in the fetus, especially in those with G6PD deficiency. It is not used for radical cure in pregnant women and is deferred until after delivery.

 

Option C. Quinine: While quinine can be used if there is resistance to chloroquine, it is not the first-line treatment for Plasmodium vivax.

 

Option D. Artesunate: Artesunate is the drug of choice for Plasmodium falciparum malaria but not for Plasmodium vivax in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy

 

  • Chloroquine – 600 mg base P.O. followed by 300 mg 12 hours later. Then 300 mg daily for next 2 days.
  • To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery.
  • For radical cure, primaquine should be postponed until pregnancy is over.
  • Parasites resistant to chloroquine should be given quinine under supervision.
  • Patients with severe anemia may need blood transfusion.
  • Folic acid 10 mg should be given daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia.
  • Complicated malaria: Artesunate IV 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12 and 24 hours, then daily thereafter. Oral therapy (2 mg/kg) is started when the patient is stable.
  • Alternatively, Quinine IV followed by oral therapy is given.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl born out of non-consanguineous marriage presented with rachitic changes in limbs since 1½ years of age for which she has received multiple courses of vitamin D. Investigations showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypophosphatemic rickets

 

The clinical scenario of a child with resistant rickets and the following laboratory findings—normal serum calcium, normal parathyroid hormone, decreased serum phosphate, increased alkaline phosphatase, decreased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, increased urinary phosphate, decreased urinary calcium, and normal ABG and serum creatinine—is highly suggestive of hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Hypophosphatemic Rickets: This condition is characterized by low serum phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, leading to rickets despite normal or elevated levels of vitamin D. It is often caused by mutations affecting phosphate-regulating genes like PHEX.
  • Laboratory Findings: The hallmark of this condition includes low serum phosphate, high alkaline phosphatase, normal serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D dependent rickets: This would typically show low calcium and elevated parathyroid hormone levels due to impaired vitamin D metabolism or action. Serum phosphate may also be low, but the distinguishing factor is the response to vitamin D therapy, which is absent in hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition usually presents with low calcium and high phosphate levels due to insufficient parathyroid hormone. The given case has normal calcium and low phosphate, making hypoparathyroidism unlikely.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: This would typically show elevated serum creatinine along with abnormalities in calcium and phosphate metabolism. The normal creatinine level in this patient rules out chronic renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low serum phosphate, normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, commonly due to PHEX gene mutations.

questions.text: The given congenital anomaly develops due to non-fusion of:  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a preauricular sinus, a congenital anomaly characterized by a small opening or pit near the external ear. This condition arises due to incomplete fusion during embryonic development.

 

  1. Embryological Development: The external ear develops from six small hillocks of tissue that form around the 1st pharyngeal cleft, derived from the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches. These hillocks eventually merge to form the pinna (external ear).
  2. Non-fusion of Pharyngeal Arches: If there is incomplete or improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches, a preauricular sinus may form. This sinus can present as a small pit or dimple in front of the ear and can sometimes become infected or form cysts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arch: This is incorrect. The structures formed by the 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arches do not contribute to the formation of the external ear and thus are not involved in the formation of preauricular sinuses.

 

Option C. 1st and 2nd pharyngeal pouch: This is incorrect. The pharyngeal pouches form internal structures such as the tonsils, thymus, and parts of the ear's auditory tube but are not involved in the formation of preauricular sinuses.

 

Option D. 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouch: This is incorrect. These pouches are involved in forming structures like the thymus and parathyroid glands and do not play a role in the formation of the external ear or preauricular sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preauricular sinuses result from the incomplete fusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryonic development, leading to the formation of a small pit or tract near the external ear.

choices.text: Not given after 6 months of age
Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine

questions.text: All are true about Rotaviral vaccine except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Not given after 6 months of age

 

The Rotaviral vaccine is included in the National Immunization Schedule of India and is primarily available in two types: Rotavac and Rotasil.
 

 

Note -

 

  • The vaccine is typically given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age under NIS, with the possibility of extending the schedule up to 12 months in cases of delayed immunization.
  • Both vaccines are live attenuated, but VP8 subunit vaccine is also available, offering more strain specificity and showing good results in infants, adolescents, and adults.

 

However, it is incorrect to state that the vaccine is "Not given after 6 months of age," as it can be administered up to 12 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subunit vaccine: This statement is true as there is a subunit vaccine for rotavirus, specifically the VP8 subunit V protein vaccine, which has shown good results in various age groups.

 

Option C. Oral route of administration: This is correct. Rotaviral vaccines are given orally.

 

Option D. Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine: This is also correct. Rotavac is a monovalent vaccine, and Rotasil is a pentavalent vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rotaviral vaccine can be given up to 12 months of age according to the National Immunization Schedule of India.

choices.text: Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter
Defective peristalsis
Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus
Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus 

 

Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

 

The LES relaxes during swallowing due to the release of nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide from inhibitory neurons, as well as the interruption of normal cholinergic signaling. These inhibitory neurons degenerate in achalasia cardia, resulting in decreased NO and VIP release. This results in increased LES tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter: This is incorrect. In achalasia cardia, there is incomplete relaxation of the LES, not relaxation.

 

Option B. Defective peristalsis: While this statement is related to achalasia cardia, it is not the most accurate or complete description of the pathology. The correct answer focuses specifically on the decreased release of NO and VIP, which directly explains the increased LES tone and subsequent symptoms.

 

Option D. Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter: This is incorrect. In achalasia cardia, the tone of the LES is increased, not decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows:

 

  1. Incomplete relaxation of LES
  2. Increased tone of LES
  3. Absent peristalsis (aperistalsis)

questions.text: Which bones are cut during external DCR?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maxillary, lacrimal

 

In external Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR),  the maxillary bone is involved because it forms part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity and part of the orbit. The lacrimal bone is also involved because it contains the lacrimal sac fossa. The surgery involves creating a direct opening between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity by removing part of the lacrimal bone and the adjacent part of the maxillary bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethmoid, Sphenoid: The ethmoid and sphenoid bones are part of the skull's cranial base and are not typically involved in an external DCR. The ethmoid bone does contribute to the medial wall of the orbit and contains the ethmoid air cells, while the sphenoid bone is part of the skull base and contains the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option B. Ethmoid, Lacrimal: The lacrimal bone is a small bone forming part of the eye socket, and it is indeed involved in DCR as it forms part of the lateral nasal wall and houses part of the nasolacrimal duct. The ethmoid bone, as mentioned, is part of the medial orbital wall but is not typically cut during an external DCR procedure.

 

Option D. Nasal, Lacrimal: The nasal bone forms the bridge of the nose and is not typically modified during an external DCR. The lacrimal bone is involved in the procedure as mentioned, but the nasal bones are not cut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an external Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), the maxillary and lacrimal bones are cut to establish a new tear drainage pathway from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity.

choices.text: Start breastfeeding as soon as possible
Clear eyes with a sterile swab
Bath to newborn with warm water

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled birth attendant. Incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled birth attendant is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Bath to newborn with warm water

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended as it can cause rapid heat loss and hypothermia in the infant. Instead, after delivery, the newborn should be wiped clean with a sterile cloth and wrapped warmly without giving a bath. The bath can be delayed until at least 24 hours after birth or later when the baby’s body temperature has stabilized, especially in settings without advanced care facilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start breastfeeding as soon as possible: It is recommended to initiate breastfeeding immediately after birth, ideally within the first hour for vaginal deliveries and within 4 hours for cesarean sections. Early breastfeeding provides the newborn with essential nutrients and antibodies and helps stimulate milk production.

 

Option B. Clear eyes with a sterile swab: Clearing the eyes of a newborn with a sterile swab is correct. If needed, antiseptic solutions like 1% silver nitrate or 1% tetracycline ointment can be used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum, an eye infection that can occur in newborns.

 

Option D. Cover baby’s head and body: Covering the baby’s head and body immediately after birth is essential to prevent heat loss. Newborns lose up to 75% of their body heat through the head, making it crucial to keep the baby warm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Newborns should not be bathed immediately after birth to prevent hypothermia; instead, they should be wiped clean and kept warm by wrapping them appropriately.

questions.text: Preferable time for IUCD insertion in a 28-year-old woman who has just delivered a healthy newborn. It was a normal vaginal delivery. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Up to 48 hours

 

Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) insertion timing can be categorized into three main periods:

 

  1. During Menstruation: IUCD insertion during menstruation is preferred within the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle to ensure the woman is not pregnant and to ease insertion due to the open cervical os.
  2. Immediate Postpartum: The best time for postpartum IUCD insertion is within the first 48 hours after delivery. If not done within this window, insertion can be performed up to 1 week postpartum. This timing is optimal as the cervix is dilated, and there is a reduced risk of expulsion compared to later periods.
  3. Post Puerperal: If IUCD insertion is not performed immediately postpartum, the next preferred timing is 6 to 8 weeks after delivery when the uterus has involuted and stabilized.

 

For this question, since the woman has just delivered, the most precise and preferred time is within the first 48 hours postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most preferable time for IUCD insertion after a normal vaginal delivery is within the first 48 hours postpartum to take advantage of the naturally dilated cervix and minimize expulsion risk

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss and ascites. The patient does not have any evidence of cirrhosis and her coagulation profile is normal. Ascitic fluid analysis showed elevated adenosine deaminase. What can be done next? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start ATT

 

In countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis, such as India, the presence of elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA) in ascitic fluid is highly suggestive of abdominal tuberculosis (TB). ADA is a useful diagnostic marker for TB, particularly when its levels are significantly elevated (e.g., above 39 IU/L). Given the clinical context of weight loss, fever, and ascites, along with a high ADA level, it is reasonable to initiate anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) without further invasive testing. Starting ATT and monitoring the patient's response is an effective and practical approach, especially in resource-limited settings. This strategy avoids unnecessary invasive procedures like peritoneal biopsy, which should be reserved for cases where there is doubt about the diagnosis or if the patient does not respond to initial therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peritoneal Biopsy: While peritoneal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing peritoneal TB, it is invasive and resource-intensive. In high-prevalence areas, where elevated ADA levels strongly suggest TB, initiating ATT is preferred.

 

Option C. Observation: Given the significant clinical symptoms and elevated ADA levels, mere observation is not appropriate. Delay in treatment could lead to worsening of the patient’s condition.

 

Option D. Laparotomy: Laparotomy is an invasive surgical procedure and is not warranted for diagnosing TB when non-invasive methods like ADA testing and clinical presentation strongly suggest the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In high-prevalence countries for tuberculosis, elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA) in ascitic fluid, along with clinical signs, is sufficient to start anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) without the need for invasive procedures.

questions.text: A patient presented with violent, flinging movements. Where is the lesion causing the hemiballismus seen? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subthalamic nucleus

 

Hemiballismus is characterized by involuntary, violent, flinging movements, typically on one side of the body. This condition is most commonly associated with a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus. The subthalamic nucleus plays a crucial role in regulating movements, and damage to this area can lead to the excessive, uncontrolled movements seen in hemiballismus. This differentiates it from lesions in other parts of the basal ganglia, which are associated with different movement disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Putamen: Lesions in the putamen are more commonly associated with chorea, which involves rapid, involuntary, and irregular movements, rather than the violent flinging movements of hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Caudate nucleus: Similar to the putamen, lesions in the caudate nucleus typically result in chorea. The caudate nucleus is part of the striatum, and its dysfunction does not usually present with the violent movements characteristic of hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Globus pallidus: Lesions in the globus pallidus often result in athetosis, which involves slow, writhing movements. This is different from the abrupt and forceful movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemiballismus, characterized by violent, flinging movements, is most commonly caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiency causes xerophthalmia and follicular hyperkeratosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is well known to cause a range of clinical manifestations, primarily affecting the eyes and skin. Key signs and symptoms include:

 

  • Xerophthalmia: This condition includes dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea, which can progress to keratomalacia and lead to blindness if untreated.

 

 

  • Follicular hyperkeratosis: This is characterized by excessive keratin deposits in hair follicles, leading to rough, bumpy skin.

 

 

Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining healthy vision, immune function, and skin integrity. Its deficiency can result in:

 

  • Night blindness
  • Immunosuppression: Leading to increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Skin ulceration and corneal ulceration
  • Atrophy of urinary and respiratory tract epithelium, increasing the risk of infections in these areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin: Deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

 

Option C. Biotin: Deficiency can cause dermatitis, alopecia, and neurological symptoms.

 

Option D. Vitamin B6: Deficiency can cause anemia, dermatitis, and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

 

  • Laterally, the fibres of the iliopubic tract fan out with fascia iliaca.
  • The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia immediately posterior to the inguinal (Poupart's) ligament.
  • It runs superolaterally from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and arches across the front of the femoral sheath.

 

 

The muscle has a broad attachment medially into the pubic tubercle and pectineal line, situated behind the conjoint tendon. On the lateral side, its fibers spread out within the fascia transversalis and fascia iliac without being attached to the iliac spines.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract is not a thickening of the lumbar fascia. Instead, it is a thickened band of the iliopectineal fascia, which is an extension of the transversalis fascia. It runs parallel and posterior to the inguinal ligament (Poupart's ligament).

 

Option B. It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract runs parallel to and posterior to the inguinal ligament (also known as Poupart's ligament). It forms the inferior border of the internal inguinal ring and provides a posterior boundary for the femoral canal.

 

Option C. It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon: This statement is not accurate. The iliopubic tract doesn't insert into the pubic tubercle. Instead, it runs laterally from the pubic tubercle, posterior to the inguinal ligament, and continues as the iliopectineal arch or fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As the iliopubic tract moves laterally from the pubic tubercle, its fibers fan out and blend with the fascia of the iliacus muscle (often referred to as the iliac fascia or fascia iliaca). This provides a connection between the structures of the anterior abdominal wall and the pelvic sidewall.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of peripheral artery disease presents with symptoms of intermittent claudication and ischemic rest pain in the lower extremities. Further evaluation reveals a significant stenosis in the femoropopliteal artery. The patient is scheduled for a femoropopliteal bypass procedure, and the surgeon must choose the appropriate graft material for the procedure. Which is the best graft for a femoropopliteal bypass?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Great saphenous vein

 

The great saphenous vein, an autologous vein graft, is considered the gold standard for femoropopliteal bypass, especially for below-knee procedures. The great saphenous vein has superior patency rates and fewer complications compared to synthetic grafts in this setting. When available and of good quality, the GSV is the preferred choice for femoropopliteal bypass. The great saphenous vein is the best as it lasts longer than polytetrafluoroethylene, Dacron and human umbilical vein as a graft in a femoropopliteal bypass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dacron: Dacron is a brand name for a type of polyester fiber. It has been used as vascular graft material for several years. Dacron grafts are synthetic and durable, and they are primarily used for larger vessel grafts such as aortoiliac or aortofemoral bypass procedures. However, for femoropopliteal bypass, especially for below-the-knee grafts, Dacron is associated with lower patency rates compared to autologous vein grafts.

 

Option C. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE): Polytetrafluoroethylene (often known by the brand name Teflon) is a synthetic material used as a vascular graft. PTFE grafts are most commonly used when a suitable autologous vein is not available. PTFE has acceptable patency rates, especially for above-the-knee femoropopliteal bypasses. However, for below-the-knee grafts, the GSV usually outperforms PTFE in terms of long-term patency.

 

Option D. Short Saphenous Vein: The short saphenous vein runs along the back of the calf and drains into the popliteal vein. While it can be used as a graft for femoropopliteal bypass, it is not as commonly chosen as the great saphenous vein. The GSV is generally longer, more superficial, and easier to harvest, making it the preferred autologous graft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great saphenous vein is the preferred graft material for femoropopliteal bypass due to its superior patency rates and longevity compared to synthetic grafts like Dacron or polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE).

questions.text: What is the type of pelvis shown below? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gynecoid Pelvis

 

Explanation:

 

Given image shows a Gynecoid pelvis.

 

Based on the shape of the inlet female pelvis can be divided into 4 types: Gynecoid (50%) Android (25%) Anthropoid (20%) and platypelloid (5%) (Caldwell-Molloy anatomical classification)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gynecoid pelvis, which is slightly oval or round in the transverse axis, is the most common and ideal type for childbirth.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page 403, William’s textbook of Obstetrics page 34

questions.text: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liver iron concentration

 

  • Children with thalassemia who undergo multiple blood transfusions are at risk of iron overload, which can cause significant damage to organs such as the liver, heart, and endocrine glands.
  • Monitoring liver iron concentration is the best method to assess iron overload in such children, as it is an indicator of total body iron stores.
  • Liver iron concentration can be measured invasively using a liver biopsy or non-invasively using T2 MRI of the liver. The latter is preferred due to its non-invasiveness.
  • Treatment for iron overload in thalassemia patients typically involves the use of chelation therapy, which helps to remove excess iron from the body. Deferoxamine is typically given through intravenous or subcutaneous infusion, while deferasirox and deferiprone can be given orally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI T2 myocardium: Quantitative iron overload in the heart is determined using a T2 MRI of the myocardium. However, it can be done sooner if there are symptoms of severe iron overload. It is often performed in children older than 10 years. If the patient's transfusion and chelation histories are unknown, it can still be done.

 

Option C. Serum ferritin: Although serum ferritin is elevated, other inflammatory disorders also cause it to be elevated, making it a less sensitive marker.

 

Option D. NTBI (Non-transferrin-bound iron): Iron in plasma is typically bound to cccc. However, when there is an excess of iron, it is unable to bind to transferrin, which results in the formation of non-transferrin-bound iron. (NTBI). It may serve as a marker for iron excess, however albumin, citrate, and uric acid in the plasma all have an impact. As a result, it cannot be utilized as a tool to quantify iron overload and serve as a guide for designing chelation therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method to detect iron overload in a patient receiving repeated blood transfusions is Liver iron concentration.

questions.text: Beta hCG is structurally similar to which biochemical moiety? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LH

 

The Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) has a biological activity similar to that of Luteinizing Hormone (LH).

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a glycoprotein having a molecular weight of about 39,000 and much the same molecular structure and function as luteinizing hormone secreted by the pituitary gland. Its most important function is to prevent involution of the corpus luteum at the end of the monthly female sexual cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FSH: Incorrect. Although FSH is also a glycoprotein hormone, it has a different function and structure compared to hCG.

 

Option C. ACTH: Incorrect. ACTH is a peptide hormone involved in the stress response, with a different structure and function compared to hCG.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Incorrect. Oxytocin is a peptide hormone involved in labor and milk ejection, with a different structure and function compared to hCG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta hCG is structurally and functionally similar to Luteinizing Hormone (LH). Its primary role is to support the corpus luteum during early pregnancy, preventing its involution.

choices.text: Fetal lung fluid
Maternal plasma

questions.text: Major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal urine

 

Explanation:

 

  • Fetal urine production begins from 8-11 weeks period of gestation
  • In the first trimester, amniotic fluid is generally composed of extracellular fluid secreted across the amnion via trans membranous flow; across the fetal vessels on placental surface via intramembranous flow; and via transcutaneous flow across fetal skin.
  • Fetal urine is the major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal skin: While fetal skin does contribute to amniotic fluid in the first trimester through transcutaneous flow, it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.

 

Option C. Fetal lung fluid: Fetal lung fluid contributes to the amniotic fluid but not as significantly as fetal urine post 20 weeks.

 

Option D. Maternal plasma: Maternal plasma contributes indirectly to amniotic fluid via transmembranous flow, but it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal urine is the major contributor to amniotic fluid volume post 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used for estimating for hemoglobin levels. What does it measure? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acid hematin

 

The instrument shown in the image is a Sahli’s Hemoglobinometer, which is used to estimate hemoglobin levels in the blood. The principle of this method is based on the conversion of hemoglobin into acid hematin.

 

PRINCIPLE OF SAHLI’S HEMOGLOBINOMETER

 

Blood is mixed with an acid solution so that hemoglobin is converted to brown-colored acid hematin. This is then diluted with water till the brown color matches that of the brown glass standard. The hemoglobin value is read directly from the scale.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sahli’s Hemoglobinometer estimates hemoglobin levels by converting hemoglobin into acid hematin, which is then compared to a color standard.

questions.text: Shield ulcer is seen in:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spring catarrh

 

A shield ulcer, is a specific type of corneal ulcer characterized by its unique shape resembling a shield or crescent. These ulcers typically occur in the peripheral cornea and are often associated with certain inflammatory or allergic conditions of the eye, such as vernal keratoconjunctivitis (spring catarrh) or atopic keratoconjunctivitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis - Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is an inflammatory condition of the conjunctiva characterized by the formation of small, raised lesions called phlyctenules. These lesions can occur on the conjunctiva or cornea and are often associated with underlying conditions such as tuberculosis or staphylococcal infection.

 

Option C. Atopic keratoconjunctivitis - Atopic keratoconjunctivitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the conjunctiva and cornea that occurs in individuals with a history of atopic dermatitis (eczema) or other allergic conditions. It is characterized by severe itching, papillary conjunctivitis, and corneal involvement, which may include the formation of shield ulcers.

 

Option D. Cataract - Cataract is a clouding of the lens of the eye that leads to a decrease in vision. While cataracts can cause various visual disturbances, they are not typically associated with the formation of shield ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spring catarrh, also known as vernal keratoconjunctivitis, is a chronic allergic condition of the conjunctiva that typically occurs in children and young adults during the spring and summer months. It is characterized by symptoms such as itching, redness, and photophobia, and may lead to the development of shield ulcers on the cornea.

questions.text: A middle aged Indian male came to Derma OPD with the lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

  • The lesion in the image presents as a pearly nodule with telangiectatic vessels, which is characteristic of BCC.
  • This type of skin cancer most commonly occurs in sun-exposed areas, such as the face.
  •  The central ulceration and rolled borders are also indicative of BCC.
  • Given the appearance and the location on the face, BCC is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC):

 

  • SCC lesions typically present as scaly, erythematous plaques or nodules, often with a central area of ulceration.

 

 

  • They can also have a rough, sandpaper-like texture.
  • The lesion in the image does not exhibit the typical keratinized or scaly appearance that is suggestive of SCC.

 

Option C. Melanoma:

 

  • Melanoma usually presents with an asymmetrical shape, irregular borders, and multiple colors.

 

 

  • The lesion in the image does not demonstrate these features, making melanoma less likely.

 

Option D. Discoid Lupus Erythematous (DLE):

 

  • DLE often presents as erythematous, scaly plaques with atrophy and dyspigmentation, often affecting the face.

 

 

  • The lesion in the image does not show the scale or the degree of atrophy commonly seen with DLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Basal Cell Carcinoma by its pearly appearance, telangiectasia, central ulceration, and rolled borders on sun-exposed skin.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 141.1-16, 142.1

Bailey & Loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 599, 604-605, 607-609, 611

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female is presenting with the special lesions as shown in the below image. What are these lesions called as?

 (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Comedones

 

Comedones are seen in ACNE VULGARIS.

 

ACNE VULGARIS:

 

• Most common form of acne.

• Most characteristic lesion - Comedones.

• Most severe form of acne vulgaris - Grade IV / Nodulocystic Acne.

• Most severe form of acne - Acne conglobata.

 

Comedones (are considered as special lesions) are the specific lesions of acne vulgaris

 

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.

 

When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone or whitehead .

 

When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidised by the air & turns black which is known as open comedone (blackhead)

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

 

According to Global alliance algorithm for acne, Oral isotretinoin is indicated for the treatment of severe acne.

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

Image: global alliance algorithm for improving outcomes in acne

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comedones is identified as small, non-inflamed lesions found in acne, characterized by a plug of sebum and keratin within a hair follicle, presenting as blackheads or whiteheads.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.1, 90.10, 90.13, 90.32 & 90.37

questions.text: Identify the type of physical restraint given in the picture below: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hog tie

 

This type of physical restraint is called Hog tying. The method involves restraining a prisoner's hands behind his back, restraining his feet and then coupling the hand and feet restraints from the back.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Choke/carotid hold: A choke hold is a grappling hold that critically reduces or prevents either air or blood from passing through the neck of an opponent. It is commonly used in martial arts and law enforcement but is not shown in the image.

 

Option B: Carotid sleeper hold: This hold is a type of choke hold that targets the carotid arteries to induce unconsciousness. It is also used in self-defence and law enforcement but does not match the restraint method shown in the image.

 

Option D: Bar arm: A bar arm restraint involves using the arm to apply pressure to the neck or back, typically in law enforcement. It does not match the method of tying hands and feet together as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hog tying involves restraining a person’s hands behind their back, restraining their feet, and coupling the hand and feet restraints together from behind, often used as a form of torture or control.

 

Additional Information

 

Torture

 

  1. Wet submarino/ Latina  – suffocation of head in liquids/ dirty liquids

 

  1. Dry submarino: Plastic bag around face

 

  1. Telefono – beating on ear by hands

 

  1. Falanga (Bastinado): Beating on feet

 

  1. Parrot’s perch – rod placed below knees , upside down , hands tied to rod



 

6. Planton – person made to stand for long hours

             

7. Saw horse – victim sits on sharp object → injury to perineal area

 

 

8. Hog tie – Restraining a prisoner's hands behind his back, restraining his feet and then coupling the hand and feet restraints from the back.

 

9. Ghotna – wooden log rolled over the legs

 

10. Chepuwa – wooden log is compressed on legs

 

11. Black slave – hot metal rod in anus

 

12. Electric cattle prod – electric current to sensitive parts (nipple, genitalia)

questions.text: Patient with depression, which medicine is appropriate?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluoxetine

 

Fluoxetine is an SSRI (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor) and is considered the first-line treatment for depression. SSRIs are preferred due to their efficacy and better side effect profile  compared to other classes of antidepressants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lithium: Lithium is primarily used in the treatment of bipolar disorder to manage both manic and depressive episodes.

 

Option C. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication typically used for conditions like schizophrenia and delusional disorders.

 

Option D. Imipramine: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) and can be used to treat  depression. However, TCAs generally have more side effects and are less safe compared to SSRIs, making fluoxetine a more appropriate choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoxetine, an SSRI, is the first-line treatment for depression due to its efficacy and favorable side effect profile.

questions.text: What among the options serves as a factor that conditions to the development of malnutrition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Infectious diseases

 

Infectious diseases act as conditioning influences that contribute to the development of malnutrition. They can exacerbate malnutrition by increasing morbidity, leading to decreased food intake, loss of nutrients, anorexia, and overall growth failure, which in turn lowers immunity and creates a vicious cycle of poor health.

 

Other 3 Options are not considered as a conditioning influence.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of the urine specimen is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cysteine

 

  • Cystine is the oxidized dimer form of cysteine (two cysteine molecules joined by a disulfide bond).
  • Cystine, not cysteine, is excreted in urine and precipitates to form stones.
  • Therefore, cysteine is not typically found in the urine of cystinuric patients in significant amounts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid and is not typically associated with kidney stone formation. It is usually found in the urine.

 

Option B. Lysine: Lysine is another amino acid and is not commonly linked to kidney stone formation. It is typically present in the urine.

 

Option C. Cystine: Cystine is an amino acid that is known to form cystine stones, a type of kidney stone. Therefore, cystine can be found in the urine of patients with cystine stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystinuria: Cystinuria is one of the inborn errors of metabolism included in the Garrod’s tetrad. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

 

The disorder is attributed to the deficiency in transport of amino acids Signs and symptoms include:

 

  1. Abnormal excretion of cystine and to a lesser extent lysine, ornithine and arginine. Hence the condition is also called Cystine-lysinuria.
  2. Crystalluria and calculi formation. In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine
  3. Obstructive uropathy, which may lead to renal insufficiency
  4. Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test. Urine is made alkaline with ammonium hydroxide and sodium cyanide is added. Cystine, if present, is reduced to cysteine. Then add sodium nitroprusside to get a magenta-red colored complex. Specific aminoaciduria may be confirmed by chromatography.
  5. Treatment is to increase urinary volume by increasing fluid intake. Solubility of cystine is increased by alkalinization of urine by giving sodium bicarbonate.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is caused by the defect of which of the following organelles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peroxisomes

 

Zellweger syndrome is a peroxisome biogenesis disorder caused by defects in peroxisomes. Peroxisomes are essential organelles involved in various metabolic processes, and their dysfunction leads to Zellweger syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria: Zellweger syndrome is not caused by a defect in mitochondria. Mitochondria are responsible for energy production in cells, and defects in mitochondria lead to different diseases, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option B. Lysosomes: Zellweger syndrome is not caused by a defect in lysosomes. Lysosomes are responsible for breaking down cellular waste and are associated with lysosomal storage disorders, which are different from peroxisomal disorders like Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Nucleus: Zellweger syndrome is not primarily caused by a defect in the nucleus. It is a peroxisomal disorder, and the genetic mutations associated with Zellweger syndrome typically affect genes related to peroxisome biogenesis, not nuclear genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Zellweger syndrome, there are empty peroxisomes in all body cells causing defect in alpha-oxidation and oxidation of VLCFA. So, both phytanic acid and VLCFA accumulate. It is the most severe Peroxisomal Biogenesis Disorder (PBD).

questions.text: Identify the range of the firearm wound: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close Shot Entry Wound

 

  • Lot of blackening is easily visible around the firearm wound in the image.
  • Burning, blackening and tattooing are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds typically do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are generally larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds lack the features of burning, blackening, and tattooing. The wound edges are usually cleaner.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Similar to close shot exit wounds, distant shot exit wounds do not have burning, blackening, or tattooing and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

choices.text: Positive feedback
Negative feedback
Adaptive control regulation

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is seen in the baroreceptor reflex? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Negative feedback

 

Explanation

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels

 

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Increase in blood pressure → stimulates baroreceptors → Herring’s nerves → glossopharyngeal nerves →nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla→ release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) → inhibitions of rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) which is the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feedforward: Incorrect. Feedforward control involves responses that anticipate changes, typically without a direct sensor feedback component, which is not applicable to the baroreceptor reflex.

 

Option B. Positive feedback: Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies an initial stimulus, leading to an even greater response. In contrast, the baroreceptor reflex mitigates changes in blood pressure to restore equilibrium.

 

Option D. Adaptive control regulation: Incorrect. While adaptive control involves adjustment based on feedback, it is more complex and typically involves adjustments over time to control parameters. The baroreceptor reflex specifically uses a simpler, direct negative feedback mechanism to quickly counteract changes in blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The baroreceptor reflex is a prime example of a negative feedback mechanism in human physiology, crucial for maintaining stable blood pressure by counteracting deviations from an individual's normal blood pressure set point

questions.text: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure pre-ductal oxygen saturation in an infant who was born 3 minutes ago? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal right upper limb

 

To assess preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn, the recommended area to place the pulse oximeter is the right upper limb. The right upper limb is preductal, meaning it receives blood directly from the aorta before it passes through the ductus arteriosus. This positioning is crucial for detecting any discrepancies between preductal and postductal oxygen saturation levels such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

 

If the preductal oxygen saturation is more than 5% higher than the postductal saturation (measured at the foot), it suggests the presence of a right-to-left shunt.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal left upper limb: Although the left upper limb can be used, the right upper limb is preferred for preductal saturation measurement to ensure accuracy in detecting shunts.

 

Option B. Fetal left lower limb: The left lower limb is postductal, making it unsuitable for measuring preductal oxygen saturation.

 

Option D. Fetal right lower limb: The right lower limb is also postductal and not suitable for measuring preductal oxygen saturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To measure preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn, place the pulse oximeter on the right upper limb. This helps in detecting any right-to-left shunt, such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

questions.text: A patient presents with a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth, which appears bluish-red and transilluminates positively. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ranula

 

A ranula is a type of mucous cyst that forms in the floor of the mouth. It typically presents as a bluish-red, cystic swelling that transilluminates positively due to its fluid content. Ranulas are caused by the obstruction of salivary glands, leading to the accumulation of mucous.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: This is incorrect because dermoid cysts contain sebaceous material and hair, and they do not transilluminate. They are also not typically bluish-red in appearance.

 

Option C. Sublingual growth: This is incorrect as a general term that does not specify a cystic or transilluminating nature.

 

Option D. Sublingual cyst: This is incorrect as it does not have transillumination and bluish-red color.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ranula presents as a bluish-red, cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth that transilluminates positively, due to the accumulation of mucous from an obstructed salivary gland.
